questions.text:
A concerned mother takes her daughter of 14 years age who was complaining of pain in the private parts to a gynecologist. On eliciting history, the girl admits she had consensual sexual intercourse with a neighbor and refuses to get examined. What should the gynecologist do? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

 

  1. Document informed refusal
  2. Do not inform the police
  3. Counsel the mother and daughter
  4. Examine with necessary force
  5. Inform the police
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 5 are true 

 

This situation involves multiple aspects: legal, ethical, and medical considerations are paramount. Here's why each statement is addressed as true or false in this context:

 

1. Document informed refusal: True. It is essential for medical practitioners to document any refusal of examination or treatment, particularly in sensitive cases involving minors. Documentation should include detailed information about what was explained to the patient and the guardian, and their reasons for refusal, to ensure clarity and legal safeguarding.

 

3. Counsel the mother and daughter: True. The role of a gynecologist includes providing medical counseling, especially when it involves minors and sensitive issues such as sexual activity. Counseling should aim to educate about the health implications of the sexual activity, the benefits of medical examination, and the legal aspects considering the age of consent.

 

5. Inform the police: True. According to laws in many jurisdictions, including India, any sexual activity with a minor, regardless of consent, is considered statutory rape. Medical professionals are mandated reporters, which means they are legally obligated to report such cases to law enforcement to ensure the safety of the minor and adhere to legal statutes.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Do not inform the police: False. The gynecologist has a mandatory obligation to report cases of suspected statutory rape, as non-reporting could be considered a failure of duty and legal non-compliance.

 

4. Examine with necessary force: False. It is illegal and unethical to perform a medical examination against a patient's will, especially in the case of a minor. The patient's autonomy must be respected, and no examination should proceed without consent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examination of a victim of sexual assault should be done only after the consent of the victim. It is the accused who can be examined without consent, not the victim. Whether the victim agrees for examination or not, the police always have to be informed as there is an allegation of crime of rape (as sex even with consent with a girl <18 years of age will be considered rape)

questions.text: A dead body is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ligature strangulation  

 

The presence of a ligature mark that completely encircles the neck, is horizontal, and located below the level of the thyroid cartilage is indicative of ligature strangulation. This type of mark differentiates it from other forms of neck compression injuries.

 

Additional Clues:

 

  • Dribbling of Saliva: The absence of dribbling of saliva suggests that the cause of death is not hanging. Dribbling of saliva is the surest sign of antemortem hanging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Throttling: Throttling involves manual strangulation using hands, not a ligature. It would show different injury patterns on the neck.

 

Option C. Gagging: Gagging involves the insertion of a foreign object into the mouth to prevent breathing, which would show different internal and external signs.

 

Option D. Hanging: Hanging would typically show a ligature mark that is oblique and above the level of the thyroid cartilage, along with signs such as dribbling of saliva.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

questions.text: What is the cause of the condition given below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

 

The above image shows washerwoman's feet/ washerwoman's skin. It is seen in a case of immersion in water (both antemortem as well as postmortem drowning). It denotes skin maceration or swelling and wrinkling of the skin due to water absorption. Following changes are seen in washerwoman skin:

 

  • Wrinkling: After 3 hrs of immersion
  • Soddening (filled with water): After 12 hrs of immersion
  • Bleaching (whitening): After 36 hrs of immersion
  • Peeling: after 72 hrs of immersion

 

In the image, bleaching can be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic neuropathy: Diabetic neuropathy typically presents with sensory deficits, pain, or ulcers but does not cause the skin changes seen in the image.

 

Option B. Hanging: Hanging does not cause the specific wrinkling and bleaching of the skin seen in the image.

 

Option D. Burns of foot: Burns would result in charring, blistering, and other thermal injuries, not the wrinkling and bleaching seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's feet (or skin) is characterized by swelling, wrinkling, and bleaching due to prolonged immersion in water, typically observed after more than 36 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with a brown hue in postmortem lividity? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydrogen sulphide

 

Explanation:

 

Hydrogen sulphide is associated with a green or bluish-green color in postmortem lividity, primarily due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin. This distinct coloration is different from the brown hue typically seen with agents like nitrites, phosphorus, and chlorates, which contribute to darker, brownish discolorations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nitrites: Because nitrites can cause a brownish hue in postmortem lividity, correlating with their effect on blood pigments.

 

Option B. Phosphorus: Since phosphorus can lead to dark brown or black discolorations in postmortem lividity.

 

Option C. Chlorates: As chlorates are known to cause chocolate brown discolorations in postmortem lividity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrogen sulphide is associated with a green or bluish-green color in postmortem lividity, not the brownish hue seen with other listed agents.

questions.text: Death sentence can be given by: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A. Session court judge and B. Additional session court

 

Explanation:

 

In the Indian judicial system, both the Session Court and the Additional Session Court have the authority to pass a death sentence. However, any death sentence given by these courts must be confirmed by the High Court before it can be carried out. The Supreme Court and High Court can also issue death sentences directly.

 

It is important to note that the Assistant Sessions Court Judge and the Additional Sessions Court Judge are not the same. An Assistant Sessions Court Judge is a junior position and does not have the power to issue a death sentence.

 

Other Option:

 

Option. C. Chief judicial magistrate: The Chief Judicial Magistrate does not have the authority to pass a death sentence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, death sentences can be issued by the Session Court, Additional Session Court, High Court, and Supreme Court. However, any death sentence passed by the Session Court or Additional Session Court must be confirmed by the High Court before it can be executed.

choices.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis
Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens
Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from an environment presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding shown below. Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

 

The clinical presentation of pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort along with the laboratory findings suggest a diagnosis of lead poisoning. The presence of basophilic stippling in the red blood cells, as observed in the peripheral blood smear, is a hallmark feature of lead poisoning. Basophilic stippling represents aggregates of ribosomal material that remain in red blood cells due to the disruption of heme synthesis caused by lead toxicity.

 

Lead interferes with the activity of several enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, leading to defective red blood cell maturation and characteristic basophilic stippling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis: Incorrect. While viral infections can affect erythropoiesis, they do not typically lead to the basophilic stippling seen in lead poisoning.

 

Option B. Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, causing intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells: Incorrect. Lead poisoning does not cause intracellular iron accumulation but affects heme synthesis, leading to the formation of ribosomal aggregates within red blood cells, which is reflected as basophilic stippling.

 

Option C. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens: Incorrect. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia typically causes hemolysis and spherocytes in the blood smear but does not result in basophilic stippling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Students should recognize basophilic stippling as a key feature of lead poisoning, resulting from the disruption of heme synthesis and the accumulation of ribosomal material in red blood cells. This is important in diagnosing children exposed to lead, which can lead to significant anemia and other systemic effects

questions.text: Which of the following eye sign is given in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tache noire

 

The image depicts a condition known as Tache noire, characterized by a triangular brownish discoloration on the sclera. This occurs due to the deposition of bacteria and dust, usually within 3 to 4 hours after death. Tache noire is a postmortem change observed in the eyes of the deceased when the eyelids are partially open, leading to drying of the exposed sclera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kevorkian sign: This sign involves the fragmentation of blood in blood vessels into columns due to the loss of blood pressure after death. The characteristic appearance is shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. Corneal changes: These involve alterations in the cornea, such as clouding, that occur after death. However, the given image does not show corneal clouding but rather a specific discoloration indicative of Tache noire.

 

Option D. Vitreous humour changes: These refer to alterations in the vitreous humour of the eye postmortem, such as changes in its consistency or color. The image does not depict such changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tache noire is a postmortem change characterized by a triangular brownish discoloration on the sclera due to drying and deposition of bacteria and dust, typically occurring within a few hours after death.

choices.text: Abortion leading to death of mother
Preventing the child from being born alive

questions.text: IPC Section 314 deals with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abortion leading to death of mother

 

ABORTION IPC’S = 312-316 IPC’S, 317 & 318

 

312 – 316 → Criminal Abortion

 

312 – Criminal abortion with consent of mother (BNS section 88)

 

313 – Criminal abortion without the consent of mother (BNS section 89)

 

314 – Death of mother during criminal abortion (BNS section 90)

 

315 - Preventing a live birth or causing a live born to die after birth (BNS section 91)

 

316 – Causing death of quick born, by a heinous act which could have led to death of mother (ex: - hit on abdomen of mother) (BNS section 92)

 

317 - Abandoning of a child by parents when child age is <12 years (BNS section 93)

 

318 - Concealing the birth of a newborn by secret disposal of dead body (BNS section 94)

 

Educational Objective:

 

IPC Section 314 deals specifically with the death of the mother during a criminal abortion.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bhilawanol

 

  • The above image shows the seeds of Semicarpus anacardium
  • Identification: Black, heart-shaped seeds with a rough projection at the base
  • Active principles: bhilawanol and semicarpol.
  • Common name: Marking nut
  • Uses of the juice:
    • To produce an artificial bruise.
    • Juice is used by washerman/laundries to inscribe identification number on the clothes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ricin: Ricin is a highly toxic protein found in the seeds of the castor oil plant (Ricinus communis).

 

Option C. Abrin: Abrin is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the rosary pea (Abrus precatorius).

 

Option D. Calotropin: Calotropin is a cardiac glycoside found in the milkweed plant (Calotropis gigantea).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active principle of the marking nut (Semicarpus anacardium) is Bhilawanol, used in traditional practices for its staining and toxic properties.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture sustained in a motorcycle accident? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hinge fracture

 

Image shows a transverse fracture of the base of the skull that completely splits it and divide it into two halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge (‘nodding face’ sign).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Depressed fracture of skull: When a portion of fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known as depressed fracture. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Pond fracture is the other name of pediatric depressed skull fracture. It is primarily due to increased plasticity of the immature skeleton in young children. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option D) Comminuted fracture of skull: is when two or more intersecting lines of fracture divide the bone into three or more fragments resembling a spider web or mosaic pattern this is not the case in this picture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

‘Hinge’ (also called Motorcyclist):

 

  • linear fracture passes across the middle cranial fossa, separating the skull base into Ant and post halves,
  • Occurs Severe Force to side of head (e.g. in motorcycle accidents).
  • Such fractures are commonly associated with injuries of the brain stem, especially pontomedullary tears.

questions.text: The progression of Passing Off of Rigor Mortis follows which sequence? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans A. Head to foot

 

Rigor mortis is the postmortem stiffening of muscles due to biochemical changes in the muscle tissues after death. It typically starts within 2 hours after death, beginning with the myocardium (heart muscle). Externally, the sequence begins at the upper eyelids and then follows a top-to-bottom approach throughout the body.

 

The progression of rigor mortis occurs in three stages:

  • Developing Stage (First 12 hours): Rigor begins at the upper parts of the body and progresses

    downwards.

  • Fully Developed Stage (Next 12 hours): Rigor mortis is fully established.

  • Passing Stage (Last 12 hours): Rigor mortis diminishes in the same order, starting from the head

    and moving downwards, eventually leading to secondary flaccidity.

 

This sequence is known as Nysten Rule, which describes rigor mortis development from head to foot, with the exact order being eyelids, neck, jaw, face, chest, upper limbs, abdomen, lower limbs, and finally fingers and toes. 

 

Other Options:

 

B. Foot to head: This option incorrectly suggests that rigor mortis resolves from the lower parts of the body upward, which does not align with the observed pattern.

 

C. Periphery to centre: Rigor mortis does not dissipate based on peripheral versus central body regions; instead, it follows a directional sequence from head to foot.

 

D. Centre to periphery: This implies a central-to-peripheral resolution, which is not supported by standard forensic observations. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis follows a sequence known as Nysten's Rule, developing and passing from head to foot, starting with the upper body and ending with the lower extremities.

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in chronic arsenic poisoning except? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Luminous vomit

 

Luminous vomiting is a feature of yellow phosphorus poisoning, not arsenic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Raindrop pigmentation: This is a characteristic skin finding in chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Option B. Peripheral neuritis: Peripheral neuritis is a common neurological manifestation of chronic arsenic exposure.

 

Option C. Mees line: Mees lines (transverse white lines on nails) are indicative of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features seen in chronic arsenic poisoning:

 

1. Peripheral neuropathy (neuritis):         

It can occur in Arsenic , Thallium , Mercury, and Lead.                                  

Lead: Mainly motor, little bit sensory neuropathy                                                     

Arsenic, Thallium, mercury: mainly sensory, little bit motor neuropathy 

 

2) Skin symptoms:

- Hypopigmentation initially

- Rain Drop Pigmentation as shown below

 

 

- Peculiar skin rash – resembles Addison’s disease , Fading measles rash

- Hyperkeratosis of palms & soles as shown below:

 

3) Nails: Aldrich Mees Lines

Transverse whitish lines on nails (seen is Arsenic, and Thallium)

 

 

 

4) Hair: Alopecia seen in Mercury, Arsenic, Thallium (Mnemonic: Hair on MAT)

 

5) GIT: Vomiting , Diarrhoea , pain abdomen

 

6) Liver: Jaundice , Hepatomegaly , Fatty liver , Cirrhosis

 

7) Blackfoot disease: Coagulation in Peripheral blood vessels leading to Gangrene of periphery

 

8) Malignancy of almost any body part

questions.text: When Nitric Oxide is synthesized, which amino acid is produced as a byproduct? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L-Citrulline

 

Explanation:

 

During nitric oxide synthesis, L-citrulline is produced as a byproduct when L-arginine is converted to NO by nitric oxide synthase (NOS). This reaction is significant because L-citrulline can be recycled back to L-arginine through the citrulline-NO cycle, making it an important intermediate in maintaining continuous NO production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L-Arginine: L-arginine is the substrate for NO synthesis, not a byproduct. It is the amino acid that gets converted to NO and L-citrulline by NOS.

 

Option C. Glycine: Glycine is not involved in the NO synthesis pathway. While it's important for various metabolic processes, it is not produced during NO synthesis.

 

Option D. Lysine: Lysine is an essential amino acid but has no direct role in NO synthesis or production. It is not generated as a byproduct during NO formation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The synthesis of NO from L-arginine by NOS produces L-citrulline as a byproduct. This L-citrulline can be recycled back to L-arginine through the citrulline-NO cycle, maintaining the substrate pool for continuous NO production

questions.text: Which test is utilized to identify seminal stains? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Barberio's Test

 

Explanation:

 

Barberio's test specifically targets the identification of seminal stains. This forensic test employs Barberio's reagent, which contains picric acid, applied to a suspected seminal stain. A positive result is confirmed by the formation of yellow, needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate, indicating the presence of spermine from the seminal fluid reacting with the picric acid. This test is precise for seminal stains due to its unique chemical reaction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenolphthalein Test (Kastle-Meyer test): This test is used to detect the presence of hemoglobin in blood stains, not seminal stains.

 

Option C. Paraffin Test (Dermal nitrate test): This test is used for detecting gunpowder residues on the skin, typically to determine if a suspect has discharged a firearm.

 

Option D. All of the Above: Incorrect as only Barberio's Test is specific to seminal stains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barberio's test, involving the reaction of picric acid with spermine, is specifically used for the detection of seminal stains.

choices.text: Examination by Male doctor with female attendant
Vaginal swab examination is not necessary
Termination of pregnancy with her consent by a Gynecologist

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl was raped by her neighbor. She presents to the hospital with 25 weeks of pregnancy. What should not be done? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Termination of pregnancy with her consent by a Gynecologist

 

According to the MTP Act, the termination of pregnancy due to rape is allowed only upto 24 weeks. Also, since this girl is a minor (< 18 years) the consent of the guardian is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Examination by Male doctor with female attendant: Male doctor can always examine a female patient, if a female attendant is present

 

Option B) Vaginal swab examination is not necessary: Evidence of rape remains only till 96 hours. Here pregnancy is 25 weeks, so vaginal swab will not help to detect semen

 

Option C) Confirm pregnancy by USG: After 21 weeks the pregnancy can be confirmed by simple palpation of fetal parts. USG may be done for other reasons, but not to confirm pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP ACT (Latest amendment 2021)

choices.text: Frontal and maxillary sinuses are larger
Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

questions.text: Which of the following trait is a feature of the female skull? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

 

Remember: In general, most features are larger and more prominent in males. However, there are three features which are exceptionally larger or more prominent in females. Just remember these:

 

  • Frontal Eminence is more prominent in females 
  • Parietal Eminence is more prominent in females
  • Orbits are larger in females

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Larger teeth: Incorrect. Male skulls typically have larger teeth compared to females.

 

Option B. Frontal and maxillary sinuses are larger: Incorrect. These sinuses are generally larger in males.

 

Option D. Supratympanic crest is present: Incorrect. This feature is more commonly found in male skulls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are applicable to most bones, hence no need to remember separately for each bone. These are

 

Size: Male bones tend are larger than female bones.

 

Texture: The texture of male bones can be rougher and more rugged due to increased muscle attachment areas.

 

Articular Surface Size: Male bones may have larger articular surfaces compared to females.

 

Bone Markings: Bony markings where muscles and ligaments attach are more prominent in males.

 

So for individual bones, just remember the specific features, instead of general features

questions.text: Following are the reasons for thiamine deficiency COMMONLY seen, Except: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is actually a consequence of thiamine deficiency, not a cause of it. It's a neurological complication that occurs due to severe thiamine deficiency, most commonly seen in chronic alcoholics. The syndrome consists of acute Wernicke's encephalopathy and chronic Korsakoff's psychosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bariatric Surgery: This is a valid cause of thiamine deficiency due to malabsorption following surgical alteration of the gastrointestinal tract. The reduced absorption surface and altered anatomy directly impact thiamine absorption.

 

 

Option B. Chronic Alcoholic: Alcoholism is a major cause of thiamine deficiency due to poor dietary intake, impaired absorption, and increased metabolism of thiamine. Chronic alcohol use interferes with thiamine uptake and utilization.

 

Option C. Chronic Use of Diuretics: Loop diuretics especially can cause thiamine deficiency by increasing its urinary excretion. This is particularly significant in patients on long-term diuretic therapy for conditions like heart failure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is a consequence rather than a cause of thiamine deficiency. Understanding this distinction is crucial for proper diagnosis and treatment of thiamine deficiency states.

questions.text: Basiocciput fuses with basisphenoid at what age? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 18-22 years

 

The fusion of the basiocciput with the basisphenoid occurs at around 18-22 years of age. This process is part of the normal skeletal development during late adolescence and early adulthood.

 

Fusion Age: The fusion of these bones is a significant event in the maturation of the cranial base, occurring between the ages of 18 and 22 years. This fusion helps in the formation of a solid and stable base for the skull.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fusion of Basiocciput with basisphenoid is seen around 18-22 years.

questions.text: In a case of fatality resulting from firearm injuries, the entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar. The firearm's firing distance probably is? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Distant range

 

An abrasion collar is a ring of abraded skin around the entrance wound of a bullet. It is caused by the bullet's friction as it penetrates the skin. This feature can be found at any distance, including distant range. However, additional features such as singeing, blackening, and tattooing are present only at closer ranges. Since the question states that the entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar, it indicates that none of the other close-range features are present, suggesting a distant range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact range: At contact range, there would be singeing, blackening, and tattooing right at the margins of the wound, as well as potential muzzle imprint and burning due to the close proximity of the firearm.

 

Option B. Close range: At close range, there would be significant blackening and tattooing around the wound, indicating the firearm was discharged from a short distance but not in contact with the skin.

 

Option C. Near range: At near range, there would still be some blackening and tattooing around the wound, but these features diminish with increasing distance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are five features of firearm entry wound (inner most to outermost):

 

  • Grease Collar (inner most)
  • Abrasion collar
  • Singeing
  • Blackening
  • Tattooing (outer most)

 

Out of these five features, Abrasion collar and Grease collar can be found in any entry wound, irrespective of the distance between victim and firearm. This is because these are produced by bullet itself as it enters the body.

 

Whereas Singeing, Blackening and Tattooing occur only upto a limited distance

questions.text: A patient came with complains of hair loss. His wife mentions that she has noticed some behavioral changes. The doctor notices that there is a loss of eyebrows on the lateral side. He then comes to a conclusion by examining the nails. What is the type of poisoning in this case? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thallium

 

  • Alopecia is the most characteristic feature of Thallium, especially loss of eyebrows on lateral side
  • Both thallium and arsenic have many similar features (both have Mees lines, peripheral neuropathies, GI symptoms, skin symptoms etc.) But the key differentiating feature is thallium is associated more with alopecia, whereas, arsenic more with GI symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning presents with Mees' lines, peripheral neuropathies, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Alopecia can occur, but it is more closely associated with gastrointestinal symptoms than with hair loss.

 

Option C. Mercury: Mercury poisoning can cause alopecia, but it is also associated with tremors, irritability, and renal issues.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning is associated with gastrointestinal symptoms and neurological issues such as abdominal pain and peripheral neuropathy but not typically with alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alopecia is seen in Thallium, arsenic and mercury poisoning
  • Mees lines in nails are seen in Thallium and Arsenic poisoning

questions.text: A gynecologist performs a hysterectomy for endometrial carcinoma. Despite the adequate precaution, the ureter was injured intraoperatively. The gynecologist is not held responsible under? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medical maloccurence 

 

The gynecologist cannot be held responsible for the above act under medical maloccurence.

 

Medical maloccurence/Inevitable Accident: 

 

  • It is defined as an unfavorable outcome, but not resulting from malpractice.
  • Despite giving best treatment patient may fail to respond properly or may suffer some adverse reactions of the drug leading to temporary or permanent deformities. This is known as a medical maloccurence/inevitable accident.
  • If the doctor can prove this before the court, it will be an absolute defense against malpractice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Novus actus interveniens: This legal term refers to a new intervening act that breaks the chain of causation, leading to a result that might not have been foreseeable. This does not apply here as the injury was directly related to the surgical procedure, not an external unrelated event.

 

Option C. Res ipsa loquitor: Latin for "the thing speaks for itself," this doctrine applies in cases where the injury would not typically occur without negligence. This option would suggest a presumption of negligence because such injuries usually do not occur without a breach in the standard of care. However, the context given indicates precautions were taken, so this is not the best answer.

 

Option D. Physician error: This implies a mistake made by the physician that could lead to legal liability. In this scenario, it was noted that all standard precautions were followed, thus excluding this option as the appropriate answer given that no specific error or negligence was cited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical maloccurence is critical to understand that not all adverse outcomes in medicine result from negligence. Some are inherent risks of medical procedures despite the highest standards of care. Recognizing this helps in managing patient expectations and can protect healthcare providers in cases where complications arise despite proper precautions.

questions.text: Which feature is not characteristic of an antemortem blood clot?(NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chicken Fat Appearance

 

Explanation:

 

The "Chicken Fat Appearance" is not a characteristic of antemortem clots but rather of postmortem clots. Antemortem clots are typically well-formed, adherent to the vessel wall, and display a laminated structure with visible lines of Zahn—alternating layers of lighter staining platelets and fibrin with darker red blood cells. These features indicate active biological processes that occur before death, involving clotting factors and cellular elements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laminated: Antemortem clots are indeed laminated, showing organized layering of blood components.

 

Option B. Rubber and Firm: This describes the texture of an antemortem clot, which is elastic and strong due to the active clotting process.

 

Option D. Contains Platelets: True for antemortem clots, as platelets are actively involved in the clotting process that occurs prior to death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antemortem clots are laminated, firm, and contain platelets, whereas a "Chicken Fat Appearance" is indicative of a postmortem clot.

questions.text: Which of the following poisons cause bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on postmortem examination? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium amytal

 

Sodium amytal poisoning is known to cause bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on postmortem examination. This distinctive feature helps in identifying the presence of this substance in cases of poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxalic acid

 

  • Symptoms: Severe abdominal pain, vomiting, hypocalcemia, renal failure.
  • Postmortem Findings: Erosion and ulceration of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. Soneryl

 

  • Description: A barbiturate used as a sedative-hypnotic.
  • Postmortem Findings: central nervous system depression.

 

Option D. Atomic number 33 (Arsenic)

 

  • Symptoms: Gastrointestinal distress, garlic-like odor on breath, multi-system organ failure.
  • Postmortem Findings: Hemorrhagic gastroenteritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on postmortem examination is a characteristic finding in sodium amytal and copper sulphate poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following tests relies on the principle that prior knowledge of events or activities will influence a suspect's physiological responses? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Brain Mapping

 

Brain mapping is based on the principle that if a suspect has prior knowledge of an event or activity, it will be reflected in their brain wave responses. This technique involves measuring electrical brain wave responses (P300) to familiar stimuli, such as words, phrases, or pictures, presented on a computer screen. The P300 wave is an event-related potential (ERP) component elicited in the process of decision-making and is used to detect the recognition of familiar information. When a suspect recognizes the stimuli related to the event or activity, their brain produces a distinct response that can be measured and analyzed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Truth Serum: Truth serum refers to drugs used to make a person more likely to divulge truthful information. These drugs work by depressing the central nervous system to the point where the subject is less capable of resisting questioning and less likely to lie. It does not rely on physiological responses to prior knowledge.

 

Option B. Polygraph: The polygraph test measures physiological responses such as heart rate, blood pressure, and skin conductivity to determine if a person is lying. It is based on the theory that deceptive answers will produce physiological changes due to the emotional responses associated with lying, such as fear or anxiety. However, it does not specifically rely on the prior knowledge of events or activities.

 

Option C. Hypnosis: Hypnosis involves putting a subject into a trance-like state where they may be more open to suggestions and potentially recall forgotten details. It does not rely on physiological responses related to prior knowledge and is not primarily used for detecting deception based on prior knowledge of events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain mapping detects recognition of familiar stimuli through brain wave responses, reflecting a suspect's prior knowledge of events or activities

questions.text: Saturnine gout is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lead poisoning

 

Saturnine Gout:

 

  • Description: Saturnine gout is a type of gout caused by chronic lead intoxication. This can result from occult or occupational exposure to lead, or from the ingestion of moonshine (illegally produced alcohol that may contain lead contaminants).
  • Incidence: Accounts for less than 5% of gout cases.
  • Mechanism: Lead induces tubulointerstitial renal damage, which impairs the kidneys' ability to excrete uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia (excessive uric acid in the blood).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Similar to primary gout, but with a predilection for affecting the knee more than the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe).
    • Hyperuricemia in Saturnine gout exceeds the reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR), meaning the high uric acid levels are disproportionate to the kidney's filtration capacity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cadmium poisoning: Symptoms: Kidney damage, osteomalacia (bone softening), and respiratory issues.

 

Option C. Beryllium poisoning: Symptoms: Respiratory problems, chronic beryllium disease (CBD), and lung cancer.

 

Option D. Mercury poisoning: Symptoms: Neurological and behavioral disorders, kidney damage, and gastrointestinal disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Saturnine gout is a specific type of gout caused by chronic lead poisoning, characterized by hyperuricemia and tubulointerstitial renal damage.

questions.text: A person who at the time of commission of the offense was of unsound mind, is exempt if he didn't know the nature of the act or its consequences. This rule is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McNaughton rule

 

The McNaughton rule, also known as the legal test or right-wrong test, is the standard used in India to determine criminal responsibility for individuals with mental illness. According to this rule, a person is exempt from criminal responsibility if, at the time of the commission of the offense, they were suffering from a mental disorder that rendered them incapable of understanding the nature of their act or knowing that it was wrong. This rule emphasizes the individual's ability to understand the act, rather than their ability to control their behavior.

 

The rule is codified in Indian law under Section 84 Indian Penal Code (IPC) (Now, 22 BNS) and has been the primary standard for assessing the criminal liability of mentally ill offenders in India. If a person can understand that their actions are wrong, they are held responsible; otherwise, they are not.

 

Additional Information

 

Various rules related to the criminal responsibility of mentally ill individuals:

 

  • McNaughten Rule: This is a legal test that focuses on whether the person knew right from wrong at the time of the offense. This is also referenced in Section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).
  • Irresistible Impulse Test: Indicates that a person is not responsible if they acted on an uncontrollable impulse despite knowing the act was wrong.
  • Durham Rule: A person is not criminally responsible if the unlawful act was the product of a mental disease or defect.
  • Currens Rule: States that a person is not responsible if they lacked the capacity to conform to the requirements of the law.
  • American Law of Institute Test: A person is not responsible if they lacked:
    • Adequate capacity to appreciate the criminality of their conduct due to a mental disease or defect (cognitive insanity).
    • Adequate capacity to conform their conduct to the requirements of law (volitional insanity).
  • Doctrine of Partial Responsibility: This implies that while a person may be responsible, their mental illness is considered as a mitigating factor, potentially leading to reduced culpability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Durham's rule: This rule states that an individual is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act was the product of mental disease or defect. It focuses on the presence of a mental disease or defect as the cause of the unlawful act, rather than the individual's understanding of the nature of the act.

 

Option C. Currens rule: This rule states that an individual is not criminally responsible if they lacked the capacity to conform their conduct to the requirements of the law due to mental illness. It emphasizes the individual's ability to conform their behavior to legal standards.

 

Option D. Irresistible impulse test: This test states that an individual is not criminally responsible if, due to mental illness, they were unable to control their actions or resist the impulse to commit the act, even if they understood the nature of the act and that it was wrong.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, the McNaughton rule is used to determine criminal responsibility for individuals with mental illness. According to this rule, a person is exempt from criminal responsibility if they were unable to understand the nature of their act or know that it was wrong due to their mental condition.

choices.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patient

 

“Onus of proof” implies the responsibility to prove or disprove a crime.

 

As a general rule, the onus to proof lies with the victim (or his lawyer), and not with the accused, in both civil and criminal cases. The accused is assumed to be innocent. It is the responsibility of victim (or his lawyer) to prove that accused has done a crime.

 

In criminal case, the burden of proof is always on the state (i.e., the public prosecutor, the government lawyer for victim). The state must prove that the accused is guilty.

 

In civil case, the burden of proof lies on the plaintiff. The plaintiff is a person who brings a case against another in a civil court. The person against whom the case is filed is called defendant. For e.g. in a medical negligence case, the patient is the plaintiff and the doctor is the defendant. Ordinarily the patient (and his lawyer) has to prove that the Doctor is negligent.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Police not under rank of sub inspector: Involved in criminal investigations but does not bear the onus of proof in civil negligence cases.

 

Option C. Magistrate: Presides over legal proceedings but does not bear the onus of proof.

 

Option D. Doctor: The doctor is the defendant in a negligence case and does not bear the initial burden of proof.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exceptions where onus of proof lies with accused:

 

  • RES IPSA LOQUITOR (the thing or action speaks of itself)
  • Insanity: If the defendant wishes to claim that he/she is insane, and therefore not guilty, the defendant bears the burden of proving his/her insanity.
  • 114-A CrPc: In a case of rape, where sexual intercourse by the accused is proved and the question is whether it was without the consent of the woman alleged to have been raped, the court shall presume that she did not consent. The accused will have to prove that it was with consent.
  • Contributory Negligence: If a doctor wants to take the defense of contributory negligence, then he will have to prove that the patient was also negligent along with him.

questions.text: Skull of a dead person was found during investigation. Police asked the relatives to bring the photo of deceased. Which of the following method can be used for identification of dead body? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superimposition.

 

Craniofacial superimposition is a technique used in the field of forensic anthropology to assist in the analysis of an unknown skull. The photograph of the missing person is superimposed on the photograph of the skull of a missing person. It is an exclusionary evidence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anthropometry (Bertillon’s System, Bertillonage)

 

  1. The science of measuring the body parts constitutes Bertillon’s system  or  anthropometry.
  2. It is only applicable in adults. After the age of 21 years the skeleton stops growing and hence the measurements of various parts of the body remain constant.
  3. It is also assumed that no two people will have bones of identical dimensions.

 

Option B. Dactylography:

 

  • The study of fingerprints for identification.
  • Useful for identifying living persons or well-preserved bodies but not applicable for skeletal remains.

 

Option D. DNA Fingerprinting:

 

  • Analysis of DNA to identify individuals.
  • Highly accurate but requires biological samples such as hair, blood, or tissue, which may not be available with skeletal remains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superimposition is the appropriate method for identifying a skull using a photograph of the deceased, by comparing anatomical features to establish a match.

questions.text: In gunshot injury to skull with entry wound at right temporal region surrounded by abrasion collar & tattooing and an exit wound at left temporal region along with metal fragments of bullet inside the bullet track, what can be used to determine the range of firing? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hair  

 

The singeing of hair, along with blackening and tattooing, can be used to determine the range of firing in gunshot injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Bullet pieces: They can be present irrespective of the distance

 

Option C) Blood: Not helpful to determine distance

 

Option D) Clothes: Not helpful as the bullet wound is on head. In other body parts clothes would have been helpful

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  • Contact Shot: Singeing, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  • Close Shot: Singeing, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  • Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  • Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text: Pick the mechanism of death in cold water drowning? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vagal inhibition

 

  • In cold water drowning cause of death is Cold shock response/ hydrocution / immersion syndrome.
  • It is a series of neurogenic cardio-respiratory responses caused by sudden immersion in cold water.
  • Death results from vagal inhibition of the heart, i.e., cardiac arrest occurring due to increased stimulation of the vagus nerve by
  • Sudden entry of water into the nasopharynx or larynx
  • Diving into the water in a manner that is suddenly strikes the abdomen
  • Sudden in-rush of cold water into the ears

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asphyxia: Common in other types of drowning but not the primary cause in cold water drowning.

 

Option B. Laryngeal spasm: Can contribute to asphyxia but is not the primary mechanism in cold water drowning.

 

Option D. Cardiac arrest: While cardiac arrest occurs, it is due to vagal inhibition, not directly from cold water exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cold water drowning, the primary cause of death is vagal inhibition, leading to cardiac arrest due to the sudden stimulation of the vagus nerve from cold water immersion.

questions.text: A vegetarian COVID patient, recovering at home, developed numbness and tingling in hands and feet. Despite taking multivitamin supplements regularly, symptoms persisted. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely causing these symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency is common in vegetarians and can cause neurological symptoms including peripheral neuropathy (numbness and tingling in hands and feet). COVID-19 infection can worsen B12 deficiency due to reduced absorption and increased metabolic demands. Regular multivitamins may not contain sufficient B12 to correct severe deficiency, especially in vegetarians who lack dietary sources.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D deficiency: While common during COVID recovery due to reduced sun exposure, vitamin D deficiency primarily affects bone health and immunity. It doesn't typically cause peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 deficiency: Although B6 deficiency can cause neuropathy, it's rare in people taking multivitamins. Excess B6, rather than deficiency, is more commonly associated with neuropathy.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 deficiency: Niacin deficiency (pellagra) presents with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Peripheral neuropathy is not a primary feature.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency should be suspected in vegetarians presenting with peripheral neuropathy, even if taking multivitamins. COVID-19 can exacerbate nutritional deficiencies through reduced absorption and increased metabolic demands. The condition requires specific B12 supplementation, as regular multivitamins may be insufficient

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry mouth, dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, and delirium. What could be the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dhatura


Dhatura poisoning is associated with anticholinergic toxidrome, which presents with features such as dry mouth, dilated pupils, dry skin, slurred speech, and delirium. Anticholinergic substances like Dhatura inhibit the action of acetylcholine, leading to reduced secretions, dilated pupils, and central nervous system effects like confusion and delirium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid and falls under the category of CNS depressants. Opioids typically cause pupil constriction (miosis), not dilation, and do not produce dry skin or dry mouth, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Alcohol: Alcohol, especially in the early stages, may cause pupil dilation but usually presents with wet skin and slurred speech due to CNS depression, not dry features. Dry skin and mouth are not characteristic of alcohol intoxication, making this option incorrect.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Cocaine is a sympathomimetic agent, which can cause pupil dilation but does not cause dry mouth or dry skin. Cocaine typically increases body secretions rather than reducing them, so this does not fit the anticholinergic profile described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:


Dhatura poisoning exhibits an anticholinergic toxidrome characterized by dry mouth, dry skin, dilated pupils, and altered mental status, distinguishing it from other toxidromes.

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary crystals as shown in the image below. What can be the cause? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ethylene Glycol

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by the formation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine. When ethylene glycol is ingested, it undergoes metabolic conversion in the body to glycoaldehyde, which is then converted to glycolic acid, glyxolyic acid, and finally oxalic acid. Oxalic acid combines with calcium in the body to form calcium oxalate crystals. These crystals are excreted in the urine and can cause significant renal damage, potentially leading to renal failure. Additionally, the formation of calcium oxalate crystals depletes calcium levels in the body, leading to symptoms of hypocalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methyl Alcohol: Methyl alcohol, or methanol, is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid, which primarily cause metabolic acidosis and visual disturbances. It does not lead to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine.

 

Option C. Aconite: Aconite poisoning affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, causing symptoms such as hypotension, arrhythmias, and paresthesias. It does not result in the formation of urinary crystals.

 

Option D. Organophosphate poisoning: Organophosphate poisoning affects the nervous system by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, leading to an accumulation of acetylcholine. Symptoms include muscle twitching, respiratory distress, and bradycardia. It does not cause calcium oxalate crystals to form in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning leads to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, which can cause renal failure and hypocalcemia

questions.text: According to the WHO grading shown in the image, which stage of Vitamin A deficiency is considered reversible with treatment? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) XN to X2

 

Explanation:

 

The early stages of Vitamin A deficiency (XN through X2) - which include night blindness (XN), conjunctival xerosis (X1A), Bitot's spots (X1B), and corneal xerosis (X2) - are completely reversible with appropriate Vitamin A supplementation. These stages represent the initial manifestations of deficiency before permanent structural damage occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. X3A to X3B: These stages represent corneal ulceration (less than and greater than 1/3 of corneal surface respectively). At this stage, the damage may result in permanent scarring even with treatment.

 

Option C. XS to XF: XS (corneal scarring) and XF (xerophthalmic fundus) represent end-stage changes that are typically permanent and irreversible, even with Vitamin A supplementation.

 

Option D. All stages: This is incorrect because while early stages (XN to X2) are reversible, later stages involving corneal ulceration, scarring, and fundus changes may result in permanent damage despite treatment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency is crucial for identifying which stages are reversible with treatment. Early intervention before corneal ulceration (before X3A) offers the best chance for complete recovery.

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. i-3, ii-4, iii-1, iv-2 

 

i. Mummification - Image 3. It is a method of embalming the dead body. It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air.

 

ii. Adipocere - Image 4. It forms under warm and humid weather due to hydrolysis of lipids.

 

iii. Marbling - Image 1. In marbling, blood vessels are visible on the skin as greenish-black streaks and eventually results in skin discoloration ranging from green to black, due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

 

iv. Postmortem lividity - Image 2. Livor mortis, also known as postmortem hypostasis or postmortem lividity, is a passive process of blood accumulating within the blood vessels in the dependent parts of the body as a result of gravity, causing a discoloration of the skin that varies from pink to dark purplish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mummification: Occurs in dry or warm environments, preserving the body by desiccation.
  • Adipocere: Forms in warm, humid conditions through the hydrolysis of lipids, leading to a waxy transformation of body fat.
  • Marbling: Blood vessels become visible as greenish-black streaks due to sulphmethemoglobin formation, appearing within 24 hours and becoming prominent by 36-48 hours.
  • Postmortem Lividity: Blood accumulates in dependent body parts due to gravity, causing discoloration from pink to dark purple.

questions.text: A dead body is recovered from a river. The body has signs of antemortem drowning and also has multiple wounds as shown below. What can be the cause of these wounds? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Self-inflicted

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows multiple superficial, parallel incised wounds on the forearm, which are characteristic of hesitation marks. Hesitation marks are typically seen in cases of suicide attempts where the individual makes multiple superficial cuts while hesitating to make a final, deeper cut.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Active self-defense wound: Incorrect because active self-defense wounds are found on the front of the hands and forearms and usually involve a struggle, not multiple, superficial, parallel cuts.

 

Option C. Postmortem artifact: Incorrect because postmortem artifacts do not present as multiple, organized, parallel incised wounds.

 

Option D. Passive self-defense wound: Incorrect because passive self-defense wounds are found on the back of the hands and forearms and are typically blunt force injuries, not superficial cuts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key points to understand about the different types of wounds:

questions.text: All the following are used for identification of a dead body except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nail

 

Less commonly used due to challenges in extracting sufficient DNA unless recent under-nail samples are available for identifying substances or DNA remnants.

 

Other Options:

 

The various tissues used for identification of a deceased individual vary in their utility and reliability.

 

Option A. Muscle: Can be used for DNA profiling, especially when other tissues are degraded.

 

Option B. Blood: Highly useful for DNA extraction and toxicological analysis to help in identification and determining cause of death.

 

Option D. Hair: Useful if the hair contains follicles; provides DNA which can be crucial for identification purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While nails can sometimes provide useful information, such as traces of substances the individual may have been in contact with, they are less reliable for DNA-based identification compared to other tissues like blood or hair with follicles.

questions.text: Examination of suspicious stain shows the image below. Which test is this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio

 

The image shows yellow needle-shaped crystals, which are characteristic of the Barberio test. The Barberio test is used to identify the presence of spermine and spermidine, substances commonly found in semen stains. The appearance of yellow needle-shaped crystals is a distinctive feature of this test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence: The Florence test produces dark brown rhombic crystals, not yellow needle-shaped crystals. This test is used to detect choline, another component of semen, and does not match the crystals shown in the image.

 

Option C. Teichmann: Also known as the Hemin test, the Teichmann test is used to confirm the presence of blood and produces dark brown rhombic crystals, similar to the Florence test. It does not produce yellow needle-shaped crystals.

 

Option D. Takayama: The Takayama test, or Hemochromogen test, produces pink feathery crystals. It is used to confirm the presence of blood but is visually distinct from the yellow needle-shaped crystals shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Barberio test is identified by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals and is used for detecting spermine and spermidine in semen stains

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine

 

STRYCHNINE NUX VOMICA

 

Active Principle: Strychnine, Brucine

 

Most Toxic part: Seeds (Fatal dose: 1 crushed seed; uncrushed seed not toxic)

 

MOA –

 

  • Competitive antagonist of glycine at post synaptic receptors
  • Strychnine inhibits the uptake of glycine, which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter at post-synaptic junction which gives excitatory effects
  • Spinal Cord: Anterior horn cells & brain stem also.

 

Clinical Presentation –

 

  • Very sudden onset
  • Dramatic presentation
  • “Conscious seizures”
    • Generalized
    • Simultaneous Convulsions (2-3 mins): All muscles affected at once
    • In b/w contractions muscles completely relaxed (5 mins)
      • Death occurs after 5-6 convulsions (1-2 hrs)

 

1. Opisthotonos: Hyper extension of spine

 

2. Emprosthotonus: Forward bending of spine (Sometimes)

 

3. Pleurosthotonus: Sideways bending of spine (Sometimes)

 

4. Risus Sardonicus: Contraction of facial muscles leading to smiling face

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ricinus communis (Castor) poisoning leads to burning pain in throat, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea and death.

 

Option C: Nerium odorum (cardiac poison) causes headache, dizziness, vomiting, low blood pressure, fibrillation, AV block, coma, and death can occur due to cardiac failure.

 

Option D: Datura poisoning show symptoms like

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strychnine poisoning presents with characteristic "conscious seizures" and back arching (opisthotonos) due to its antagonistic action on glycine receptors.

questions.text: The most common organ that injures in air blast-shock wave is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lungs

 

Explanation:

 

In an air blast or shock wave, the most common organs injured are the tympanic membrane (eardrums), lungs, and gastrointestinal tract (GIT), in that order. Since the tympanic membrane is not included in the given answer options, the correct answer among the available choices is the lungs, which are the second most commonly affected organ in an air blast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Kidney: Although the kidneys can be injured in an air blast, they are not the most common organ affected.

 

Option. C. Bones: While fractures can occur due to the impact of an air blast, bones are not the most frequently injured structures compared to the lungs.

 

Option. D. Skeletal muscle: Skeletal muscle injuries can happen in an air blast, but they are not the most common type of injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an air blast or shock wave, the lungs are the most common organ injured among the given options, following the tympanic membrane. In contrast, the gastrointestinal tract is the most frequently affected organ in underwater blast injuries.

questions.text: A servant was sexually assaulted by her boss. There was presence of white stains on the clothes of the victim. Barberio's test was performed on the stains. Which of the following is detected by this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spermine

 

  • Barberio’s test detects the presence of spermine (prostatic component of semen).
  • In this test the alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to dried seminal stain which produces the yellow needle shaped crystals are of spermine picrate.

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Acid phosphatase: It is detected in acid phosphatase test

 

Option C) Choline: It is detected in Florence test

 

Option D) Fructose: Produced by Seminal vesicles, but not commonly detected

 

Educational Objective

 

Tests for seminal stains

 

1) Presumptive test for seminal stains:

 

  • Fluorescence under UV light
  • Microchemical tests: ﻿﻿Florence test and ﻿Barberio's test   

 

2) Confirmatory Tests for Semen

 

  • Detection of complete sperm under the microscope (Best test)﻿﻿
  • Acid phosphatase test (second best test): It is produced by prostate gland. Acid phosphatase enzyme in semen is much higher concentration than other body fluids
  • ﻿﻿Creatine phosphokinase test: It is a component of Spermatozoa.
  • Prostate specific antigen

choices.text: White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a woman who was reportedly discovered near a village lake. Among the listed factors, which one does not indicate drowning prior to death:(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Washerwoman's hands and feet

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet just indicates that body was immersed in water. It does not specify whether the person died due to drowning or not. It occurs due to infiltration of water into the outer layers of the skin, which will occur irrespective whether the person died due to drowning or the body was thrown in water after death.

 

 

If a body is recovered from water, the there are two different kind of signs to look for:

 

  1. Signs of Antemortem Drowning: These will indicate that person died due to drowning.
  2. Signs of Immersion: These will only indicate that the body was in water.

 

Signs of Antemortem Drowning (in descending order of accuracy):

 

  • Grass or weeds tightly held in hands (cadaveric Spasm): Surest sign
  • Drowning Froth Over Mouth and Nose and in air passages: Second best sign
  • Emphysema Aquosum (overinflated lungs)
  • Presence of sand / mud etc. in respiratory passages especially in terminal part
  • Diatom test
  • Presence of water especially if mixed with mud / sand etc. in Stomach or intestines
  • Paltauff Haemorrhage (Subpleural Haemorrhage)
  • Gettler’s test

 

Signs of Immersion

 

  • Washerwoman’s hand / feet
  • Cutis anserina=goose skin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water in stomach: This suggests that the person was alive when entering the water and swallowed water, indicating antemortem drowning.

 

Option C. White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils: This foam, often referred to as "drowning froth," is a strong indicator of antemortem drowning as it forms when water mixes with air and mucus in the airways.

 

Option D. Positive diatom test: The presence of diatoms in the organs indicates that the person inhaled water while still alive, allowing these microscopic algae to enter the bloodstream and be deposited in various tissues, thus confirming antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet indicate immersion in water but do not specify drowning as the cause of death, unlike other indicators such as water in the stomach, white leathery foam, and a positive diatom test, which strongly suggest antemortem drowning.

questions.text: In 18th century British East India company used to transport which substance of abuse to China: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opium

 

Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the British East India Company exported vast quantities of opium to China, leading to widespread addiction and the Opium Wars, which had significant geopolitical consequences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marijuana: A psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Option D. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China.

questions.text: A factory worker was brought to the emergency room after consuming wood spirt with complaints of headache, vomiting and blurred vision. What treatment will you give the patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fomepizole

 

Given case is of methanol poisoning and can be managed by giving Fomepizole.

 

Methanol Poisoning

 

Symptoms – Occur 12-24 hours after ingestion.

 

Patient usually presents with nausea, vomiting, abdomen cramps, spirit-like smell from mouth and nostrils. Headache, dizziness, vertigo, restlessness, dyspnea are other features. Pupils are fixed and dilated leading to blurred vision (snowfield vision). In later stages, patient lands up in metabolic acidosis.

 

Treatment –

 

  • Gastric Lavage by 5% NaHCO3 solution.
  • Oral NaHCO3 to combat acidosis
  • Calcium folinate/leucovorin to reduce blood format levels.
  • Administration of ethanol as competitive antagonist
  • Antidote: 4-methylpyrazole (fomepizole) is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase.
  • Hemodialysis in case of severe poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flumazenil is an antidote for Benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Option B. N-Acetyl cysteine is an antidote for Paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option C. Naloxone is an antidote for Opioid overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fomepizole is the appropriate treatment for methanol poisoning as it inhibits the conversion of methanol to its toxic metabolites by blocking alcohol dehydrogenase.

choices.text: Hymen does not rupture because opening is too small to allow penis to enter
The hymen does not rupture because Hymen is situated deep inside

questions.text: If a young female child is raped, the hymen is usually: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both a and b

 

Rape on Children:

 

In rape of a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because of two reasons:

 

  • Vaginal opening is very small, hence penetration very difficult. Usually, the penis is placed either within the vulva or between the thighs. And as such, only redness and tenderness of vulva may be caused.
  • Hymen is deeply situated, hence even if some penetration occurred, it is not ruptured.

 

Also, in a child, there may be no signs or very few signs of general violence since the child has no idea of the act and is also unable to offer resistance.

 

However, in rare cases of great violence, the penis may be forcibly introduced, causing rupture of the vaginal vault, Hymen and associated visceral injuries. In this case the injuries will be more severe than adults and such injuries might result in death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of rape involving a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because the vaginal opening is very small, making penetration difficult, and the hymen is situated deeply. Additionally, children may not show signs of general violence due to their inability to resist, though severe injuries can occur in cases of great violence.

questions.text: An accused died in lock up during the police interrogation. Enquiry in this case will be done by? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Judicial magistrate

 

Enquiry in a case of death of police custody/firing will be done by Executive magistrate.

 

Please remember that Custodial death is the only condition where inquest is mandatory to be done only by judicial Magistrate.

 

In India two types of Inquest are held- Police and Magistrate.

 

Magistrate inquest is of further two types- Executive magistrate and judicial Magistrate.

 

Inquest Sections:

 

  1. 174 CrPc: Police Inquest (It is the commonest inquest and Done in all Inquests other than those specified in 176 Crpc)
  2. 176 CrPc: Magistrate Inquest. It is of two types:
  3. Executive Magistrate:  
    • Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage 
    • Exhumation. 
  4. Judicial Magistrate: Done in Custodial Deaths

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Executive Magistrate: Handles inquests for dowry deaths and exhumations but not custodial deaths.

 

Option C. Police IG (Inspector General): Does not conduct inquests; senior police officer overseeing police operations.

 

Option D. Head Constable: Can conduct police inquests but not mandated for custodial deaths, which require a Judicial Magistrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of inquest are as follows:

 

 

Ref: KSN Reddy, Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd Ed., p. 132

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

 1. Cocaine - b. White lady

 

  • Cocaine is known by various street names such as snuff, rock, crack, coke, snow, Cadillac, and white lady.

 

2. LSD - c. Purple wedge

 

  • LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is referred to by names like acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, Deeda, purple Owleys, purple wedges, The Beast, The Chief, The Ghost, The Hawk, and white lightning.

 

3. Abrus precatorius - d. Gunchi

 

  • Abrus precatorius, also known as Indian liquorice, prayer beads, crab's eye, weather plant, gulagunchi, ratti, and gunja, is a plant known for its toxic seeds.

 

4.  Capsaicin - a. Hunan hand

 

  • Capsaicin, the active component in chili peppers, is known to cause burning sensations on the skin, particularly the hands, leading to the term 'Hunan hand.'

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct matches are Cocaine with "White lady," LSD with "Purple wedge," Abrus precatorius with "Gunchi," and Capsaicin with "Hunan hand."

questions.text: A 33-year-old male with attempted poisoning was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state. His pulse was 140/min, respiratory rate -30/min. His ABG showed metabolic acidosis. Urine analysis showed Calcium oxalate crystals. Identify the likely poison?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ethylene glycol

 

The presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a key diagnostic sign of ethylene glycol poisoning. Metabolic acidosis and drowsiness is also indicating towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formaldehyde is ruled out because the patient’s symptoms like, metabolic acidosis, and the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, do not align with the typical effects of formaldehyde poisoning, which usually involves respiratory and mucous membrane irritation.

 

Option C. Paraldehyde While drowsiness and metabolic acidosis can be associated with paraldehyde poisoning, the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a characteristic feature of ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Option D. Methyl alcohol (methanol) While drowsiness and metabolic acidosis can be associated with methyl alcohol poisoning, the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a characteristic feature of glycol poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning

 

Ethylene glycol is the major constituent of antifreeze solutions. It is a clear, colorless, odorless, non-volatile liquid with a bitter-sweet taste.

 

Action: Ethylene glycol itself is not toxic, but the toxicity is due to metabolites glycolic and oxalic acids which inhibits oxidative phosphorylation.

 

  • Oxalic acid combines with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals which accumulates in the proximal convoluted tubules causing renal failure.
  • Metabolic acidosis occurs from glycolic acid.
  • Ingestion of ethylene glycol produces CNS depression which may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps. Metabolites of ethylene glycol produce severe metabolic acidosis and damage to the brain, heart, and kidneys

 

Treatment - Sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole.

questions.text: Match the following weapons with the possible injuries caused by them: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

 

Mechanism of Injury with the Following Weapons:

 

A. Axe - 4. Chop wound: Axes are heavy and have a sharp edge, causing deep, gaping wounds that are classified as chop wounds.

 

B. RTA (Road Traffic Accident)- 3.Grazed abrasion: In RTAs, the skin may be scraped off, resulting in grazed abrasions due to friction against the road surface.

 

C. Blade- 1. Incised wound: Blades are sharp-edged tools that cause clean, sharp cuts known as incised wounds.

 

D. Lathi - 2. Tram track wound: A lathi, or baton, is a blunt object that can cause parallel linear bruises known as tram track wounds when struck with force.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of injury with the following weapons:

questions.text: A person working in a restaurant comes to the casualty with a huge burn on his abdomen. On examination, the injury looks like below. What is the most likely cause of the injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Moist heat

 

  • In the case scenario given above the patient has suffered from a ‘Scald injury’

  • Clinical presentation - erythema, blisters, and a line of demarcation

  • Cause of scald - application of liquid above 60°C or from steam which is moist heat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electric burn: Electric burns typically have entry and exit points and are caused by electrical currents passing through the body, which is not seen in the image.

 

Option B. Chemical burn: Chemical burns result from exposure to corrosive substances and may have different patterns and additional signs such as discoloration or tissue damage beyond just blisters and erythema.

 

Option C. Dry heat: Burns caused by dry heat, such as flames or hot objects, usually present with charring or a different burn pattern compared to scald injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of the burn injury shown in the image is moist heat, specifically a scald injury caused by hot liquids or steam.

 

TYPES of SCALD INJURIES

 

  • Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water.

  • Accidental Splash burns

  • Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

questions.text: During fetal autopsy, what is the order of examination to differentiate between live and stillbirth? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Head > Abdomen > Thorax

 

During a fetal autopsy, the abdomen is typically examined before the thorax to assess the level of the diaphragm. The position of the diaphragm can indicate whether respiration has taken place. If the diaphragm is at the level of the 4th to 5th rib, it suggests that respiration has not occurred. If it is at the level of the 6th to 7th rib, it indicates that respiration has taken place. Although there is no strict rule about the order of examining the head, it is generally preferred to examine the head first to check for any hemorrhages. The correct sequence provided in the options is Head > Abdomen > Thorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thorax > Abdomen > Thorax: Incorrect. This option repeats the thorax examination and does not include the head, which is important for checking for hemorrhages.

 

Option B. Thorax > Head > Abdomen: Incorrect. The abdomen should be examined before the thorax to check the diaphragm level, which is crucial for determining whether respiration has occurred.

 

Option D. Head > Thorax > Abdomen: Incorrect. This option does not follow the necessary sequence where the abdomen should be examined before the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a fetal autopsy, the correct sequence of examination is Head > Abdomen > Thorax, with the abdomen being opened before the thorax to check the diaphragm level for respiration evidence

questions.text: Identify the rules used as tests of insanity? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both A and B

 

  • Durham's rule and Curren's rule are used in cases as tests for insanity.

  • The Durham's rule states, “an accused is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act was the product of mental disease or mental defect”.

  • The Curren's rule states that “an accused person will not be criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of law, as a result of mental disease or defect”.

 

Educational Objective:
